definition:
A Hausdorff topological space $X$ is called *collectionwise normal* if
any discrete collection of sets $\{U_i\}$ in $X$ can be covered by a
pairwise-disjoint collection of open sets $\{V_j\}$ such that each $V_j$
covers just one $U_i$. This is equivalent to requiring the same property
for any discrete collection of closed sets.

A Hausdorff topological space $X$ is called *countably collectionwise
normal* if any countable discrete collection of sets $\{U_i\}$ in $X$
can be covered by a pairwise-disjoint collection of open sets $\{V_j\}$
such that each $V_j$ covers just one $U_i$. This is equivalent to
requiring the same property for any countable discrete collection of
closed sets.

Any metrizable space is collectionwise normal.

[9]{} Steen, Lynn Arthur and Seebach, J. Arthur, *Counterexamples in
Topology*, Dover Books, 1995.
